headline: US FTC says Mars' $36 billion Kellanova deal is not anticompetitive
summary: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission said on Wednesday that candy giant Mars' proposed $36 billion takeover of Pringles maker Kellanova did not meet the standard for an anticompetitive merger and that the regulator was ending its review of the deal. "Our job is to determine whether there is a violation of American law that we can prove in court. And once we've concluded there is not, our job is to get out of the way," Bureau of Competition Director Daniel Guarnera said in an FTC statement announcing the early termination of the investigation.

headline: Mars “optimistic” as EU starts in-depth probe into Kellanova takeover
summary: The EU has until the end of October to make a decision on the proposed $36bn deal.

raw.headline: Mars “optimistic” as EU starts in-depth probe into Kellanova takeover
raw.summary: The EU has until the end of October to make a decision on the proposed $36bn deal.

headline: Mars’s $30 Billion Takeover of Kellanova Comes Under In-Depth EU Investigation
summary: The European Union said it would launch an in-depth investigation into Mars’s bid to take over Pringles seller  Kellanova  escalating its probe into the nearly $30 billion deal amid concerns it could stifle competition.  The European Commission, the EU’s executive arm, said on Wednesday that both companies have strong market positions in multiple sectors and countries, with brands that are considered a “must have” for consumers.  Privately-held Mars agreed to buy Kellanova in an all-cash deal last August as part of a plan to build out its snacks business—which includes M&M’s, Twix and Skittles—with Kellanova’s portfolio of products such as Pop-Tarts and Cheez-Its.

headline: Mars' $36 billion Kellanova deal gets US antitrust approval as EU opens investigation
summary: BRUSSELS (Reuters) -Candy maker Mars' takeover of Pringles maker Kellanova was cleared by U.S. antitrust regulators on Wednesday, but their EU counterparts opened a full-scale investigation into the $36 billion deal, saying it could lead to price hikes.  President Donald Trump's antitrust enforcers, including Federal Trade Commission Chairman Andrew Ferguson, have said they will not hesitate to block deals that harm competition in ways that hurt consumers, but also vowed not to stop deals that do not pose such concerns.  The deal did not meet the standard for an anticompetitive merger, the FTC said.

The deal did not meet the standard for an anticompetitive merger, the FTC said.

headline: Mars’ $36B takeover of Kellanova delayed amid EU investigation
summary: The merger is now expected to close late this year as regulators look into how the deal could impact Mars’ bargaining power with retailers and prices for consumers.
